Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Medical Neutrality as a Strategy for Health Care Delivery in Conflict Zones

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Medical neutrality has been an influential doctrine about the noninterference of health care during periods of armed conflict. Increasingly, scientists and health care professionals have asked whether its principles can be used strategically by practitioners as a method of improving health care delivery in situations where conflict is enduring and unresolved, or in situations marked by vast socioeconomic, cultural or political differences. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, scientifically grounded fieldwork, examines how health care delivery can be improved in areas of conflict, and among and between individuals who are socially marginalized.

The project explores how medical neutrality is used as an ethical doctrine to deliver health care in a conflict arena. The research takes place in Israel, and is focused on the Palestinian doctors who make up 12% of the physicians working in Israel. The researcher asks how claims of neutrality and expertise allow Palestinian physicians to gain legitimacy and a sense of belonging within Israel. The project follows pilot research conducted in 2013 among Palestinian medical students, physicians, and administrators. The 12-month product would involve ethnographic fieldwork at four sites using a range of inductive data collection techniques, including participant observation, interviews, clinical setting ethnography, and archival media research and analysis. The project will make important contributions to medical anthropology. Importantly, the project would explore how professional scientific and technological knowledge plays a role in political and social processes, and how such expertise can create opportunities for individuals from marginalized populations. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology, the project would improve understandings for how to deliver health care in an area of conflict.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project makes use of ethnographic and archival data to trace the production and negotiation of political neutrality in everyday practices within and beyond the Israeli medical sphere. This study’s guiding proposition is that appeals to medical professionalism and political neutrality play an important role in the ways in which Palestinian physicians navigate and experience the Israeli medical system. The professional sphere presents opportunities for inclusion and social mobility for Palestinians but at the same time serves as a site of their ongoing exclusion and discrimination. I thus examine how political neutrality is understood and articulated by Palestinian physicians in the Israeli health system, how it is deployed by Palestinian physicians and how appeals to neutrality are received or resisted by Jewish and Palestinian administrators, caretakers and patients.

This dissertation project is based on a 22-month ethnographic research, conducted in the summer of 2013 and, with the support of the National Science Foundation, between June 2014 and February 2016. The research included ethnographic fieldwork in two hospital wards, 78 in-depth semi-structured interviews and media analysis.

In a wide variety of contexts worldwide, academic professionalism gives members of marginalized and minority populations a potential platform for gaining increased equality. In these contexts, expert knowledge is often perceived as a form of apolitical symbolic capital, deployable for the evasion of discrimination and the crossing of social and political boundaries. While this study follows social scientists’ continuing efforts to deconstruct these claims of political neutrality, it also acknowledges that to write “against the grain” of expertise’s neutrality is also to write against the grain of those whose hopes and needs are invested in it. Accordingly, this research approaches professional neutrality not as false consciousness, but rather as a fungible political tool in the hands of both hegemonic elites and counter-hegemonic forces. These perspectives open the way for a consideration of the medical sphere as a space of political struggle and resistance in multiple global contexts.

In the intensely emotional Israeli-Palestinian context, both sides often view neutrality as cowardly and dishonest. In academia, meanwhile, studies of expertise and medical professionalism in particular often see claims for neutrality as masking power relations and inequalities. My research problematizes this political and analytical onslaught on neutrality in order to consider its potential dangers alongside its benefits for professionals who are part of marginalized political minority. Such an approach allows a better understanding of the forces and motivations behind the reproduction of an image of neutrality, as well as the ways in which this reproduction can be seen as a politics of resistance and not only of subjugation.      

In bringing together theorizations from the interdisciplinary field of Border Studies, this study looks into the social worlds and subjectivities that are produced at geopolitical and sociopolitical borders. Critiques of exclusion practices of borders assume that their inclusive effects are desirable. But, when a Palestinian physician is highly appreciated within the hospital walls but harassed by the security guard at its gate, the need to critically address both practices of exclusion and inclusion is evident. This study of Palestinian doctors in Israel illuminates the intersections of professional and national borderlands as well as the ways in which medicine and politics intertwine at these borders.

Across the Middle East, Arabs refer to Palestinian citizens of Israel as Arab A-Dakhil (Inside Arabs), referring to their liminal position in what is perceived to be a clearly divided space – the Arab Middle East and the Jewish Israeli state. Thus, Palestinian physicians trained in Egypt, Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, Sudan, Palestine and Israel who practice medicine in Israel serve as a singular case study of medical professionalism within strongly contested borderlands. The assumed universality of medicine creates an opening for inquiry into the flow of knowledge and people across what are imagined as impermeable borders. Moreover, making visible Palestinians’ efforts to shape their individual and collective conditions of existence through medical practice provides unparalleled insights into the interactions between high status Palestinians and state institutions, Jewish elites, and Jews of lower socio-economic status. While this project complements ethnographic accounts of Palestinians’ subjugation or resistance, it also illuminates how the ideologies of the medical sphere shape their struggle in distinctive ways.
